reviewText:
Wings of Prey is comparable to that hot girl you had a crush on in high school. She was beautiful, the game is gorgeous. She had such elegance; WoP is very polished as a game. She has these abundance of little quirks (twirling hair, giggle, etc) that made you go wild, WoP has features to drool for (storyline, video replay, squadron control, etc).

Then one day you just don’t get excited to spend time together anymore, the romance fades, you realize she has no personality and is becoming obnoxious with her emotional issues. The replay ability is lost, you get frustrated with the poor aerial match-ups, there is no customization or sand box mode, and your AI enemies always seem to defy the laws of physics.

But no matter what, it was a fun ride while it lasted. 80%

reviewText:
If you're looking for a flight simulator game, but without all the fuss, and good keyboard/mouse controls, then I can highly recommend this game.

Training mode is very open and pretty much lets you do whatever you want - be that combating other fighters, or flying under low bridges in a bomber.

Unfortunaly there doesn't seem to be much of a mod scene, but overall I can highly recommend this game.

reviewText:
I had the game for 360 but decided to get it for PC so I can use my flightstick (Thrustmaster [that's what she said] HOTAS X)

So far I have yet to notice a difference in gameplay. However, the graphics look really great, I have it on ultra-turbo-awesome and it's very noticeably different from 360.

The best part is the immense configurability for joysticks. It's so good that I spent the first 45 minutes just making small changes to the layouts, including sensitivity of axes, deadzones, and non-linearity. With a little effort, you can get your dream control scheme on any joystick.

All this for $10 is a solid deal in my opinion. Will update if anything changes (about halfway through campaign so far)
voteText: 19 of 21 people (90%) found this review helpful 4 people found this review funny

reviewText:
I hadn't played this game for quite a while, but recently I did a major PC upgrade and reinstalled it.  I had forgotten what a fun little game this is.  It really sucks that the multiplayer is degraded, but it is still fun.

If you are looking for a high fidelity sim then look elsewhere.  This is not a study sim like Falcon 4, DCS A-10C, or the IL-2 Series.  It is a bit arcadey but the physics are fairly responsive and realistic and the visuals are outstanding.  Campaign missions flow in their own way, and you get to experience several different sides to WW2 flying.  With the addition of the Luftaffe DLC it seems to provide a reasonable all round experience.

Combat is a bit arcadey with fairly predictable AI and an overwhelming urge to be the lone saviour of every battle.  It is, however, easy to task wingmen to perform essential roles thus relieving you of the burden of the missio0n so you can go round shooting everything that flies :-).

As for controls, being a bit of a flight sim nutter, I used one of my simple joysticks with no issues. I cannot comment on any other control method as I have not tried them and don't really intend to.  Joystick was simple to set up and allowed me to use almost every function from the stick without having to resort ot the keyboard very often at all.

All in all this is an enjoyable semi-sim.  I would recommend it if you want an easy to get into light sim.  For a flight sim nut...probably not unless you are looking for an entertaining session of blowing s**t up.

reviewText:

Good fun but you need to put in the time.

I recommend for someone looking for a sim but anyone looking for an arcade game, go elsewhere. This is not for you.

reviewText: By default Wings of Prey is lacking. Not only is the multiplayer now obsolete (thanks in part to Gaijin's recent F2P release in WarThunder) but Wings of Prey requires the use of an external client in Yuplay which doesn't like Steam all that much. Aside from this Wings of Prey itself is a fairly by the numbers flight sim, only surpassing its competitors for visual fidelity. While Wings of Prey supports many different controller inputs, including flightsticks, the feel of the controls themselves aren't as smooth as you might hope. The single-player modes offered in this release also underwhelm for having little consistency or flow between levels and the challenge delivered, regardless of adjustable simulation settings and respawn options. Voice acting likewise varies in that English dialogue is exceedingly poor, even though native dialects sound as they should (e.g. Russian radio chatter). Don't get this game, stick to Aces High or any of the older IL-2 titles.

Slides from basically crimson skies arcade physics if you just want to shoot crap, through a full fluid dynamic aerial simulation where the wrong air mixture can stall (and kill) you as you try and keep your aging russian wreck from crashing on full featured simulation.\n\nFyi if you want a sleepless night, set all the simulation stuff to full reality, set a storm to roll in and try and land a bomber. Wings of Prey is a hybrid between a flight sim and arcade turret game. The controls are a tad complicated and missions can be repetitive; But if you're willing stick with it, there are a few fun moments in the game. A warning though, you won't be able to finish the game as the last few missions are completely bugged and broken.

PROS
-The planes are very pretty, you can see the damage sustained on the plane when you are hit.
-A lot of planes available, each feel slightly different from each other.

CONS
-many planes are only available in multiplayer
-Missions are repetitive
-The voice overs made me want to shoot myself.
-Textures on the terrain can look very ugly.
-There is a lot of waiting time during missions before any action happens

Rating: 6.9/10
One of the few Air combat" games that offers a range of handling characteristics
date: conforming to both the pick-up-and-play style
hoursPlayed: while still pulling off an extremely solid core gameplay experience.\n\nWings of Prey offers everything from grand missions that retrace the course of history and take you through the battles of WW II
voteText: sometimes making you feel like you're really fighting alongside fellow pilots.    To excruciating detail in the game's design and absolutely stunning graphics that bring the whole picture together into one fantastic package.\n\nTruly a beautiful game

reviewText:
Had a great fun playing this game!
The plying thechinque is not to hard - this is not a simulator but also doesn't make you feel like you are playing an action game. It does take some time and skill to fly right.
The battles are really breathtaking, the graphics are amazing.
One issue I've encountered -
In the demo version, the destruction engine was working really well - after every fight you could see a lot of damage on your aircraft. I don't know why, but in the full version it seems that the destruction engine doesn't work as well as in the demo. I've searched in the options menu but never found the soultion for that.
It would be great if someone here could help me out with that :)
Overall - 92/100.

This game is really a lot of fun, especially when you crank the graphics up.  It allows you to enable/disable features that change the difficulty of the game, so you can pick it up a lot quicker.  I ended up playing it (and enjoying the heck out of it) with a keyboard, but I think a joystick would make it that much more immersive.  Definitely worth the price, and certainly better than that crap HAWX 2.
Meh, it's alright... Nothing impressive and nothing too serious, fairly casual and simple. If you like aviation or ariel combat, you will like this but as I said, nothing special.

Wings of Prey is a lot more accessable than the IL-2 series and allows you to get into the game and action alot more quickly.

WoP features a ton of highly detailed aircraft that include cockpits, plus missions / gameplay spanning many combat theatres to match. There is plenty to do here in single-player, plus standard online multiplayer modes are included as well. I've gotten 100+ gameplay hours out of WoP so far.

However compared to its rivals, there are a few things lacking, notably no mission editor so you are limited beyond the missions offered and there have been some issues with multiplayer recently as support has been dropped in favour of its multiplayer-oriented sequal War Thunder.

Despite this WoP is a really great title and frankly if your into WW2 flight games you shouldn't pass up on this (even for just the single-player), however hardcore simulation fans will fill more at home sticking with the IL-2 series.

I give this game a 1.5 thumbs up with an asterick.  Do not try to play above arcade difficulty unless you have a joystick with some sort of fight feedback.  Without that tactile response, it's far to easy to bank yourself into a flat spin without even realizing it.\n\nThat said, arcade difficulty is a ton of fun.  Lots of missions, a substantial campaign that covers the three major allies, and - if you have the proper equipment, the ability to play it with simulation-level controls.

reviewText: When I first played this I thought it was the best  fighter based flight game  going.  Much better than HawX, and   streets ahead of games like Sturmovik.  It's still a  great game, but it has been superceeded by   newer titles such as the Digital Combat Simulator A-10C Warthog.  Still, this game  is exhilarating to play , challenging to complete all the missions and ithe ground   looks superb from the air;   even  when flying quite close to the ground.\n\nIt's the first    game  I remember playing where you could actually  see  shadows cast by buildings and trees as opposed to the ground being a flat photo (or, in the case of   an old favorite of mine the F19  a flat  featurless plane with the odd  vertex shape denoting hills and valleys and  line diagrams for bridges and other targets), and from a suitable height  Wings of Prey looks almost real.

reviewText:
Wings of Prey is a graphical upgrade over Il-2 Sturmovik (albeit neither a sequel to that game nor not made by the same developer), but lacks the breadth of content, realism, and general appeal of that definitive flight simulator. It is, in sum, a very average title. This is a true shame, as bonafide---as opposed to the smattering of $10 titles out there---World War II flight simulators are rare. It's sad to see a major title fall by the wayside like this.

Buy it on sale if you're a flight sim junkie, but don't expect to be wowed by it.

(Note: I have not actually played 100+ hours of this. For some odd reason, Steam several times considered the game to still be open for a long while after I had exited it.)

reviewText: I don't usually write reviews. This called for it though. There is a game called Birds of steel on xbox 360. It is basically the same game. Except in this game ( wings of prey ) the A.I. is ridiculous. I loved Birds of steel. It was such a good ww2 fighter sim. In this, you will be one of 50 allied forces flying around or floating below, and the A.I. will only aim at you. And your friendly A.I. do not do a good job of watching your back. While it takes 50 hits to kill an enemy plane, one shot will kill your weak bird. So if you can imagine being in a war except every enemy soldier only has the capability to aim at you and only you, then you can imagine this game. I played on realistic difficulty there is a degree higher called simulator which has more controls to pay attention to and enemy planes have no markers. It's not even worth it when on realistic it is IMPOSSIBLE to pass a lot of these mission without dying. Literally impossible. You will never stand a chance against 20 enemy forces who can only aim at you and no one else on the battlefield. It was fun for a minute but then it just got frustrating. Seriously frustrating. I wish it were more like Birds of steel.

reviewText:
Please note: I don't normally play Flight Simulators much and they are not really my forte. I picked this game up because it was recommended by a friend on a sale. This review will be written from that perspective.

First off, the game just won't start after installation, with the launcher just automatically closing off by itself. Hmm...not a good start at all.

For anyone who is contemplating on buying this, be forwarned.
You might need to follow the guide at this link to even get the game running.

Credits and Rep to SSnoicebox for the below solution:
Note: You will only need to do this once. If you are playing Single Player only, you will not need to log in.

http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showpost.php?p=31789933&postcount=22

Wings of Prey is a flight sim based on aerial battles across 6 theatres of WW2 in the single player campaign which lasts around 14 hours. (I admit I cheated a little and used a saved game file to get pass some missions only because they were just too difficult due to having a limited time to completing objectives. Eg: Hornet's Nest)

The graphics look very nice and detailed especially when the fighting gets furious in later missions with explosions everywhere. Music and sound effects also add alot to the atmosphere with appropriate engine sounds and wind swooshes. Another cool thing to note is when you are talking with your Wingman as a Russian Pilot, the whole conversation is in spoken in Russian with english subtitles which i felt was a nice touch. And of course with any flight sims, a flightstick is highly recommended although keyboard and mouse does the job adequately as well.

I am not a hardcore fan of flight-sims and I do not make use of any flying formations to achieve my kills so I will not be able to say if the flight physics is realistic or not for hardcore flight-sim fans.

It is rather forgiving game though in that you can have 3 modes of play (Arcade, Realistic or Simulator) and have the choice of unlimited tries even though you may get shot down in which you can just press a key to continue the fight as normal. Personally i felt that the game isn't really catered for the hardcore crowd tho, as even when you play Realistic or Simulator, the game will still provide Bomb Indicator" targeting HUD for bombing so you'll know when to drop bombs during bombing runs. I'm quite sure the real WW2 aces wouldn't have access to such a bomb targetting HUD during their time lol!

Multiplayer Co-op is only limited to the DLC Wings of Luftwaffe
date: and the whole process of getting online is absolutely tedious. To even play multiplayer
recommended: you must have signed in to the launcher when you initially launched the game
hoursPlayed: which in itself sometimes have troubles logging in. I didn't manage to get any multiplayer going on as my friend had a lot of technical troubles with Yuplay not recognizing his account
voteText: website not even recognizing his keyboard thus unable to key in any passwords etc. In short
helpfulPercent: it was just a horrible experience.\n\nIn closing
votesHelpful: I must say that this game is probably catered for people who seldom plays Flight-Sim and provides simple but not overly dumbed down controls. It will probably not appeal to hardcore fans who demand absolute realism. The single player campaign is satisfying enough with lots of interesting planes to fly around.\n\nThe biggest letdown of the whole game is the whole backend technical infrastructure
votesTotal: how it is so cumbersome to even activate the game and register an account with Yuplay
votesFunny: which IMO looks very much like those 2bit Asian Browser MMO pages for gold farmers. (No racism intended as I am Asian myself.) There is a nice game in there somewhere
commentsCount:
only if you are willing to get past all the technical hurdles and inconveniences to get to it.

Overall Rating: 6.0 / 10
(I would have rated it 7.0 had the game been easier to set up without all the frustrating technical issues)

If you are not fan of Flight Sims

reviewText: I used to really like this game, but the developers have dropped support for it, and removed the possibility to play multiplayer. When customer support is contacted, they reply that you should go play War Thunder instead. Can you believe it? I won't support this dev again, and neither should you. You'll also be forced to use YuPlay - an even more half baked client, that will make you pray for Games for Windows Live. Yes, it's truely that awful. On top of that, you will get periodic e-mails - in Russian. I'm not even joking!

reviewText:
STAY AWAY FROM THIS STEAMING PILE OF ♥♥♥♥.

While the gameplay itself is actually pretty good, the multiplayer is utter garbage.

The activation process is a form of slow torture thanks to the required yu(can't)Play client that must be running for activation (which is coded by 8 year old monkies), but unfortunately, when you try to activate the game (and any DLCs), the game 'locks' as it waits for the client to pop up the activation window, which can't come to the foreground because the game is locked because it is waiting for the client.

Don't bother trying to contact support, I'm pretty sure it doesn't exist except as a mailbox that no one actually looks at.

Also, browsing the multiplayer server list brings up an empty page.  Which means either the game is not retrieving server information, or there are actually no games taking place (likely due to the client being utter feces).  Either way, there is effectively no multiplayer in this game due to garbage code.

Save your money.

reviewText: The graphics for Wings of Prey are absolutely spectacular--very impressive. Unfortunately, I don't have a lot of experience with combat flight simulator type games so I'm not sure if they just inherently play slow--very few moments of intensity surrounded by hours of boredom. Well that's how this one came off to me. If you can fight through the boredom to get to those moments, it's a good game. But, I prefer instant gratification.

reviewText:
2/10
While I do not recommend this game, I will address all aspects: the good, the bad and the ugly. Also, please note that this was just my particular experience and not representative of all users.(Also, not sure why it's showing 65 hours of gameplay. Definately lost my patience sooner than that.)

Good: Decent graphics, well done voice overs, realistic and immersive gameplay; You really feel like you in the cockpit sometimes.

Bad: Repetive and often cheesy missions plus very non-linear difficulties (i.e. On low difficulties, I could take down a fighter with what felt like a single bullet but on mid-level difficulties I'd get shot down in within seconds of starting even the earliest missions. And to all you trolls out there, I've been playing fighter sims for years so it's not a lack of skill.)

Ugly (this is what killed the game for me): The controls were garbage. The keyboard controls made even basic maneuvers a nightmare and mapping keys to controllers wasn't much better. I tried everything from an XBox 360 controller to a joystick specially designed for WW2 fighter sims and still had trouble. One example is how each secondary weapon (bombs, rockets, etc.) had a different button assignment vice a single button and when you DO map them to the same key, you get an in-game error telling you that the secondary weapon is not available.

Overall, Wings of Prey did a good job with display and realism. But, like many games of its kind, mission variety is rather lacking but it's the crappy control scheme that makes it hit rock bottom. As I said earlier, this is just my experience with it but I highly recommend looking elsewhere.
Very fun sim, intense.\n\nBeaten only by IL-2 Sturmovik.
This is a VERY GOOD game.  This game is a good reason to buy a quality joystick. The graphics are suberb.

Very very polished WW2 flyer, alter the realism to suit, graphics alone are first rate and game play is spot on. Tactically difficult at first, get yourself a controller or joystick and practice. A whole host of aircraft and places to fly them. This game feels far better to me than War Thunder.

Graphics: 9/10 - Though somewhat old, it puts up a great show
Gameplay: 9/10 - If you buy it for what it is, its splendid
Story/Missions: 8/10 - More mission based than a story.
Multiplayer: 8/10 - Great fun, though it takes practice to rise up to human intelligence

Air combat game with attractive graphics and easy enough for average gamer not sim freak.

Should be a lot of fun, but is let down by the mission design.  You're at the controls of an aircraft and looking forward to enjoying flying it, but the missions force you to dash through and complete objectives very fast, with little margin for error.  Who tested this?

For example in one AI skirmish mission you're up against a ME190 but you'll have 1 pass at it before it races past and if you now need to turn you won't catch it before it leaves the map.  Game over.

Another mission I repeated many many times without completing in the time space, and found many other players online stuck in the same mission.

Overall a wasted opportunity.
Avoid or try it out in a sale.

Probably one of the best in the 'WWII arcade flight sim' genre, I was pleasantly surprised by the variety of aircraft and controls available. You can go for a full arcade type 'shoot-em-up' or if you turn on some of the more advanced controls and difficulty levels it can become more like a simulator. The game is also quite pretty! Only issue is that it seems to want to run some application called 'yuplay' in the background. I can't figure out what the point of it is, but if you don't turn it off after exiting WoP it still clocks up game hours on Steam so now I have apparently played 26 hours when I have only been in-game for about 3-4 of those!

Ugly (this is what killed the game for me): The controls were garbage. The keyboard controls made even basic maneuvers a nightmare and mapping keys to controllers wasn't much better. I tried everything from an XBox 360 controller to a joystick specially designed for WW2 fighter sims and still had trouble. One example is how each secondary weapon (bombs, rockets, etc.) had a different button assignment vice a single button and when you DO map them to the same key, you get an in-game error telling you that the secondary weapon is not available.

Overall, Wings of Prey did a good job with display and realism. But, like many games of its kind, mission variety is rather lacking but it's the crappy control scheme that makes it hit rock bottom. As I said earlier, this is just my experience with it but I highly recommend looking elsewhere.
Great Flight Sim with a very appealling arcade mode.

stupid...game has drm...didn't know steam started doing drm's. I would get a refund if i was allowed. I refuse to buy DRM's because i do alot of reinstalling and upgrading my system so this game will be useless in a matter of no time....thank you a holes!
easier and more arcade" like than IL-2 sturmovik games but still enjoyed this game!"

I´m a hardcore flightsimmer and i found this game is fun.

It is a nice arcade World War 2 dogflight sim, easy to learn, it is not unforgiving nor realistic as IL2, but the combats are fun, the graphics are awesome and it do a good job on recreate the places and atmosphere. You should have a joystick to play this game (or any flightsim. )

The downside is the game uses uPlay for MP, that is the worst  pile of crap ever.  I´m not sure if multiplayer is working now but probaly not because they take down all the support for this game.

Buy this game if is very cheap and if you love ww2 aviation and dogfight, you will have many hour of fun but don´t buy it if you want realistic plane behavior or multiplayer gaming.

Very fun combat flight game, it's not really a flight sim though, which some people might be glad off. Good game with good graphics, it is a very nice experience. Though it lacks some sort of varitation in the missions, sometimes the missions are impossible to beat which take away the fun! Buy it if you love a great firefight game in wwII planes! 3/5
Really nice looking!

This is one game that I feel is a must have, regardless of if you're a veteran simmer or someone with a casual interest in warplanes. The graphics are smooth and feel realistic, handling of the planes are fantastic.
Caray ¿Que queréis que os diga? Defiendes Stalingrado desde el aire junto a pilotos republicanos. Osea SI.
The Gaijin game that feels fun to play with a joystick,  albeit there's really no multiplayer anymore afaik.   Better than War Thunder because they didn't abuse people who enjoy flying with a stick.

Air combat game with attractive graphics and easy enough for average gamer not sim freak.

Should be a lot of fun, but is let down by the mission design.  You're at the controls of an aircraft and looking forward to enjoying flying it, but the missions force you to dash through and complete objectives very fast, with little margin for error.  Who tested this?

For example in one AI skirmish mission you're up against a ME190 but you'll have 1 pass at it before it races past and if you now need to turn you won't catch it before it leaves the map.  Game over.

Another mission I repeated many many times without completing in the time space, and found many other players online stuck in the same mission.

Overall a wasted opportunity.
Avoid or try it out in a sale.

Une simulation aérienne ! Chouette ! Pourquoi pas après tout ? Il faut dire que depuis le dernier Flight Simulator, le genre avait malheureusement été fort délaissé sur PC. Premier constat positif: Wings of Prey est un jeu magnifique. Les décors aux sol sont détaillés et l'ensemble des appareils jouables est modélisé à la perfection avec pour les puristes une vue cockpit" qui vaut le détour. Niveau jouabilité
date: il est préférable de se munir d'un pad (XBOX 360 de préférence) ou d'un joystick afin de  profiter au maximum et dans les meilleures conditions de l'expérience de jeu que nous propose ce titre. Accessible à tous en permetant un dosage de la difficulté allant du plus arcade au +/- simulation
recommended: il propose une quinzaine de mission permetant de revivre les plus grandes batailles de la Seconde Guerre Mondiale.\nSeul bémol: Un cuisant manque de rythme dans les affrontements."
